title: Love Is Blind  Recap , Season 8 , Episodes 1 - 6

Is the Minneapolis season of Love Is Blind gonna put the â€œmidâ€ in Midwest, or is it gonna put the 8 in gr8? I think itâ€™s too early to say after just one week, but Netflix has clearly invested a lot in season eight. As Nick and Vanessa Lachey inform the singles, this is the largest group to ever enter the pods. The food spread in the lounges seems grander, and the budget for needle drops has clearly gone up â€” blind dates are being interrupted with the likes of â€œBirds of a Featherâ€ by Billie Eilish, â€œMarry Meâ€ by Jason Derulo, and â€œWrecking Ballâ€ by Miley Cyrus. Funnily enough, using such broadly popular songs kind of circles back around to feeling as corny as using the overly specific, fake-sounding ones, so it still feels pretty on-brand to me.
The seasonâ€™s opening preview promises that thereâ€™s plenty of drama on the way, which was honestly good to know up front because the pod dates werenâ€™t initially holding my attention. Iâ€™m typically locked in and ready to binge after just an episode or two, but this week felt like more of a slow burn. There were definitely pod convos I leaned in for, and the camera crew was putting in work to capture some frankly cinematic moments in the menâ€™s and womenâ€™s lounges. However, some of the couples that got engaged werenâ€™t half as engaging to watch as the love square, where everyone went home alone. Maybe the relationships will feel more real when we see them in the real world? For now, letâ€™s unpack our six main story lines.
Love & Basketball (Devin, Brittany, and Virginia)
At the center of this love triangle is 28-year-old Devin, for whom ball is life. Heâ€™s a basketball coach who also works for a youth sports company, and he has his own basketball training business. Both of the women heâ€™s dating have a connection to the sport â€” 34-year-old partnership executive and former college basketball coach Britt-a-ny says she could beat him in a game (I believe her), while 33-year-old health-care recruiter Virginia used to be an NBA dancer. Neither of them minds the age gap, though Virginia does have a good laugh in the womenâ€™s lounge when revealing that he went to her high school after she graduated.
At first, Devin seems to be leaning toward Brittany because Virginia isnâ€™t getting as vulnerable as he wants. Brittany is the first to hear Devin talk about an injury that impacted his ability to play basketball, led to him abusing ibuprofen, and turned him closer to God. Heâ€™s touched by her lack of judgment and immediate support â€” but canâ€™t reciprocate when she nervously shares that sheâ€™s been with women, though she can only see herself marrying a man. Devin seems to struggle with the idea that there are more options than just straight or gay, and Virginia is now his clear front-runner. The ibuprofen story actually brings him closer to Virginia because of their shared desire for a partner to pray with when things get tough. In a pleasant surprise, Brittany breaks it off with Devin before he can. Iâ€™m glad that instead of him saying that her sexuality was a deal-breaker for him, she got to say that his response was a deal-beaker for her.
Virginia and Devin get engaged, and Iâ€™ve never seen anyone shake as much as she does during the reveal. But she seems happy, and heâ€™s obviously mesmerized. I can see the â€œget someone who looks at you the way Virginia looks at Devinâ€ tweets already. The way she looks up through her eyelashes is lethal.
Friends to Lovers (Joey and Monica)
(Yes, because they both have names of Friends characters. Sure, they both like swing music, but I wasnâ€™t gonna call them the swingers, was I?) According to an informal poll of my co-workers, this was the least interesting pod story line. But before we get into that, we must acknowledge Joeyâ€™s accent. The way he produces vowels â€¦ itâ€™s sauough incredible.
Anyway, Joey is a physician associate who says heâ€™s been told that he gives off golden retriever vibes. He turned down big football offers to stay near home and help his family, and he went from having $200 in his bank account after grad school to buying property when he was 27. (Care to share your methods with the class, Joey? Please?) Joey bonds with Monica â€” who is between jobs right now while she helps her grandmother â€” over their love for The Sound of Music and hatred for the sound of country music. I did enjoy when Monica attempted to teach Joey her Chilean dadâ€™s favorite dance move, but the rest of their dates before the proposal mostly felt like filler. At the reveal, Monica is surprised by Joeyâ€™s long hair, but she likes Tarzan, so it works out.
In the end-of-week preview, Joey is telling Monica about his OCD, which appears to be new information to her. What, that didnâ€™t come up in the pods, but they had time to share thoughts on monogamous penguins? They must still have a lot to learn about each other. But we see that these two at least make it as far as the altar, so thatâ€™s promising.
Social Issues (Ben and Sara)
While Joey and Monicaâ€™s screen time was too fluffy for me to feel fully invested, I had the opposite problem with developer Ben and oncology nurse Sara. We needed more fluff. Most of this coupleâ€™s screen time is devoted to Saraâ€™s hesitation around whether Ben is aligned with her on â€œsocial issues.â€ She has a gay sister, so itâ€™s important that he would be comfortable around her. Ben says he and his faith are accepting of people who are â€œthat way.â€ He has friends who are â€œthat way,â€ and he supports â€œthat community.â€ I guess itâ€™s better than a wholly negative reaction, but I donâ€™t love that he canâ€™t seem to say LGBT or gay.
In general, Sara seems to be a politically active person, while Ben says he didnâ€™t vote in the last election because he just didnâ€™t know enough. He says he has no opinion on Black Lives Matter for the same reason, which Sara side-eyes considering that theyâ€™re in the city where George Floyd was murdered. Itâ€™s just odd to see Ben be so giddy about having a girlfriend while said girlfriend is in confessionals expressing doubt because she doesnâ€™t want to have to teach fundamental values. I feel like weâ€™re missing footage that shows us more of what she likes about him. Before Ben proposes, Sara emphasizes how important social issues are to her one last time. He says he wants to grow and assures her that itâ€™s not her responsibility to teach him. He does think that they â€œwill be on the same side.â€ Again, his vague wording doesnâ€™t feel super-reassuring to me, but Sara trusts that Ben is motivated to do the work on his own, and says â€œyes.â€ Theyâ€™re very happy on reveal day â€¦ letâ€™s see how long it lasts.
Whoâ€™s More Delulu? (Dave, Lauren, Molly)
The girls are fighting â€¦ and I canâ€™t believe this is all happening over a guy who views Love Is Blind as a way to â€œconfrontâ€ himself over his history of being an â€œassâ€ to women. Dave, who works in medical aesthetics, definitely becomes our early villain with his go-to opening line in the pods: â€œSo whatâ€™s wrong with you?â€ But somehow, he pulls two women.
Lauren, who he quips is no longer attractive because sheâ€™s 30, is a former teacher who now sells curriculum to schools. She offers to help him with reading comprehension and comforts him about not returning to his childhood home before it was sold. Dave clearly imagines a certain persona based on her voice and job, and seems shocked to learn that she has a â€œfuck the patriarchyâ€ tattoo and takes nudes.
His other connection is executive bank assistant and dancer Molly, who joked to the Lacheys that the only â€œfirstâ€ she has left to give is someone being her first boyfriend/husband. Dave grins when she says there are no kinks she wouldnâ€™t try once. They both agree that life should be fun and easy, and that politics shouldnâ€™t interfere with relationships.
Molly initially doesnâ€™t know that Dave is dating Lauren, which makes Lauren wonder if all her gushing is a form of psychological warfare. (My conspiracy theory is that the camera crew gives the womenâ€™s lounge material for a fort specifically because they wanted to get those dramatically framed shots of Laurenâ€™s face hearing Molly suggest that Dave said she was his No. 1.) I start regularly rewinding to fact-check what Dave says he did or didnâ€™t say. He tells Lauren sheâ€™s the only person that he said he could see himself proposing to, but I feel like asking Molly about her ring preferences at least implied the same thing. At one point, Molly believes that Dave is going to break up with Lauren and waits through the date only to find out that he didnâ€™t; Dave later admits that he brought up the idea but didnâ€™t make any promises.
While Molly has been encouraging Dave to take his time making up his own mind, Lauren tells him to pick her and not make the wrong choice. Applying pressure is the approach that works, and Dave chooses Lauren, though heâ€™s scared of things working out and in tears thinking about how his sister will react. Right after getting dumped, Molly clears the air with Lauren, who admits that sheâ€™s been wondering which one of them is â€œmore delulu.â€ But Lauren ultimately trusts Dave, who points to his feelings via his notes about her throughout the experiment. He proposes on Valentineâ€™s Day, and they both seem happy during the reveal; Dave comes across as almost bashful in the presence of â€œmotherly, nurturingâ€ Lauren.
My concerns around this couple were centered on Dave, but the preview implies that Lauren is the one who cheats! Now the relationship feels doomed on both ends.
Breakup Central (Mason, Meg, Madison, Alex)
Not a single person leaves with a ring, but according to an informal poll of my co-workers, this was the most interesting pod story line by far. What can we say? The people love mess.
Madison is a painter who has an understandably complex relationship with her mom due to a history of substance abuse. Sheâ€™s kind of had to be a parent since she was a kid. Both she and Alex â€” a white guy who looks like Ben Platt and says he used to be ugly with a big Afro â€” have the shared experience of being bullied in school. Alex, who has ADHD and was kicked out by his family after failing high school, is now a baby-faced commercial-real-estate broker who always wants everyone to feel included. These two clearly enjoy talking to each other, but itâ€™s hard to tell how much of it is because of a real romantic spark and how much of it is just because they both understand what itâ€™s like to have gone through traumatic experiences.
Madison is also dating Joe Alwyn-skater-bro turned cinematographer-bro Mason, whose unabashed horniness brings out her flirtier side. He loves the movie Her, so this entire experience is really doing something for him. The final corner of this love square is Meg, who is, as far as I know, the first person to ever bring up Joe Rogan in the pods. When Meg shares her â€œsober highâ€ thoughts, I start to feel like Iâ€™m the one whoâ€™s high, but Mason is eating it up. He and Meg are aligned in their views on spirits, â€œenergies,â€ and conspiracy theories. They both want to find someone to be a dumb weirdo with.
In comparison, Alex seems to have more specific criteria. He asks about Madisonâ€™s attachment style, and learning that sheâ€™s avoidant seems to worry him due to past experiences with exes. But Alex pulling away makes Madison realize that she likes him, and she tries to assuage his doubts by giving up her stuffed bear for a night. They coast along for a while, declaring that they wonâ€™t take past traumas into new relationships â€¦ but hey, if it were that easy, thousands of therapists would be out of a job. Alex is scared to hear Madison say that sometimes she canâ€™t eat when sheâ€™s stressed and that thereâ€™s nothing he or anyone else can do to help her; Madison is scared that he gets too scared. But they tell themselves that they need to trust each other.
Despite â€œbaby girlâ€ Megâ€™s consistent efforts to make it clear that sheâ€™s all in on â€œZaddy Horacek,â€ Mason decides to tell Madison that heâ€™s committed to her. She makes a face and becomes Alexâ€™s girlfriend, deciding that Mason is more of a friend. Guess those cream-pie innuendos were platonic, then? After Madison breaks the news, Mason suddenly takes back his confession. In the menâ€™s lounge and on his next date with Meg, heâ€™s sticking to the story that he knew he validated the wrong person. But even Meg doesnâ€™t buy it when Mason claims that sheâ€™s always been his No. 1. She breaks up with him before he can propose (assuming that thatâ€™s what the flowers waiting for her were for). She knows she canâ€™t get over not knowing if she was just a backup, but she tells Mason not to be sorry for following his heart.
Alex and Madisonâ€™s relationship falls apart pretty quickly afterward. Although they exchange gifts and seem to be headed to a proposal, things go off the rails when Alex suggests that his friend Masonâ€™s flip-flopping feelings are just as valid as Madisonâ€™s. Her hurt manifests through taps, then tears. Alex says he canâ€™t do another relationship with miscommunication and fighting, which she feels is an unrealistic expectation. He says the missing piece is reassurance that theyâ€™ll communicate effectively, but she doesnâ€™t know if her best will always be good enough for him. This fight itself feels like proof of that, and ultimately, getting engaged is too big of a leap for Alex. In a confessional, a tearful Madison says that sheâ€™s sad but that this is the right choice.
Mr. & Mrs. Claus (Taylor and Daniel)
Thereâ€™s always a Love Is Blind couple that feels like it was invented in a Hallmark writersâ€™ room, and these Christmas lovers initially seem to fit the bill. Sales account exec and self-proclaimed short king Daniel is here to find the future mother of his children â€” someone who wonâ€™t, uh, look down on him just because heâ€™s five-eight. He jokingly gets on one knee during his first date with G.I. nurse Taylor, who ends up getting sick and has to rasp her way through several dates. An ever-growing list of coincidences and common interests helps make these two sure that they were meant to be. At one point, Daniel assures Taylor that heâ€™ll find her if she has to leave because of her dad, who has cancer. â€œIâ€™ve been waiting for you to find me,â€ she replies.
Itâ€™s easy to imagine a future where Taylor is starring in Danielâ€™s next unhinged Christmas card. (I could do without him getting a Chik-fil-A lip tattoo to match her Taco Bell one, but thatâ€™s just me.) They get engaged after reading each other letters that already sound like wedding vows. At the reveal, Daniel canâ€™t stop calling Taylor pretty. She admits to us that Daniel is shorter than her normal type but says she doesnâ€™t mind an excuse not to wear heels. Still, she seems slightly subdued.
And we learn why the next day when we see Taylor crying in the womenâ€™s hotel. â€œI have this, like, overwhelming feeling that when the doors opened last night, that was not the first time that he saw me,â€ she says, explaining that sheâ€™s fairly sure that Daniel followed and unfollowed her on Instagram not too long ago. Her account has a lot of the shared interests they bonded over in the pods, and she remembers having mutual followers. While Taylor says sheâ€™s grown to love Daniel, she seems freaked out that this might be a Joe from You situation.
In the pods, Taylor acknowledged that sheâ€™s an overthinker in relationships, and itâ€™s time for her new fiancÃ© to make good on his promise that she can ask him for clarity whenever she wants. Daniel â€” who once mentioned that he has a freakishly good memory, specifically for Instagram accounts â€” meets her at the hotel. He doesnâ€™t know why he wouldâ€™ve followed and unfollowed her and doesnâ€™t think he did. But sheâ€™s unsure. Up until now, it seemed like Taylor and Daniel exemplified the insta-love trope, where people fall hard and fast for each other. But could they actually be a story of Insta-love, where Daniel came into the pods knowing her from Instagram? Weâ€™ll have to wait to find out because this is our cliffhanger for the week.
